title: 1 Samuel Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who was ministering before the LORD in 1 Samuel Chapter 3?
options: Samuel
Eli
David
Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:1 states that the child Samuel ministered unto the LORD before Eli.

questions.question: What condition was Eli experiencing in 1 Samuel 3?
options: His eyes began to wax dim
He was deaf
He was sick with a fever
He was blind from birth
questions.correctAnswer: His eyes began to wax dim
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:2 says Eli's eyes began to wax dim, so he could not see.

questions.question: Where was Samuel when the LORD called him the first time?
options: Laid down to sleep in the temple of the LORD
Outside the temple
In Eli's house
In the fields
questions.correctAnswer: Laid down to sleep in the temple of the LORD
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 3:3, Samuel was laid down to sleep in the temple of the LORD where the ark of God was.

questions.question: How many times did the LORD call Samuel before Eli realized it?
options: Three times
Once
Twice
Four times
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: The LORD called Samuel three times before Eli perceived it as shown in 1 Samuel 3:4-8.

questions.question: What did Eli instruct Samuel to say if the LORD called him again?
options: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
Here I am, LORD
I am listening, LORD
What do you want, LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 3:9, Eli tells Samuel to say, 'Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth' if he is called again.

questions.question: What did Samuel say when the LORD called him the fourth time?
options: Speak; for thy servant heareth
Here am I
I am listening
What is it, LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Speak; for thy servant heareth
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:10 records Samuel's response, 'Speak; for thy servant heareth' when the LORD called him.

questions.question: What did the LORD say would happen to the house of Eli?
options: He will judge the house of Eli forever because of iniquity
He will bless Eli's house forever
He will make Eli's house kings
He will ignore Eli's house
questions.correctAnswer: He will judge the house of Eli forever because of iniquity
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:13 explains that the LORD will judge Eli's house forever due to the iniquity known to Eli.

questions.question: Why was the iniquity of Eli's house not to be purged with sacrifice or offering?
options: Because Eli did not restrain his sons who made themselves vile
Because Eli was a bad priest
Because the people did not trust Eli
Because the sacrifices were not acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Because Eli did not restrain his sons who made themselves vile
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:13-14 states the iniquity remains because Eli's sons were vile and Eli restrained them not.

questions.question: What did Samuel do after receiving the vision from the LORD?
options: He lay until morning and feared to show Eli the vision
He immediately told the people
He ran away
He destroyed the temple lamp
questions.correctAnswer: He lay until morning and feared to show Eli the vision
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:15 says Samuel lay until morning and feared to show Eli the vision.

questions.question: What was Eli's response when Samuel told him the vision fully?
options: It is the LORD: let him do what seemeth him good
He was angry
He ignored Samuel
He asked Samuel to lie
questions.correctAnswer: It is the LORD: let him do what seemeth him good
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 3:18, Eli acknowledges the LORD's message and accepts it.

questions.question: True or False: Samuel did not know the LORD nor had the word of the LORD yet been revealed to him at the start of the chapter.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:7 states Samuel did not yet know the LORD nor was the word of the LORD revealed to him.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD appeared to Samuel in Shiloh by the word of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:21 records that the LORD appeared again in Shiloh and revealed himself to Samuel by the word of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: The word of the LORD was common and many visions were open in those days.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:1 says the word of the LORD was precious and there was no open vision in those days.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 3:1: 'And the child Samuel ministered unto the LORD before ____.'
options: Eli
David
Saul
Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: Eli
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:1 states Samuel ministered unto the LORD before Eli.

questions.question: Complete this instruction from 1 Samuel 3:9: 'Go, lie down: and it shall be, if he call thee, that thou shalt say, ________.'
options: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
Here I am, LORD
I am listening
What is it, LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:9 contains Eli's instruction to Samuel to say, 'Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth.'

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 3 teach us about responding to God's call in our spiritual life?
options: Answer promptly and with openness
Ignore the call until sure
Ask others to interpret it first
Deny it initially to test it
questions.correctAnswer: Answer promptly and with openness
questions.explanation: Samuel answered 'Here am I' each time the LORD called him (1 Samuel 3:4, 3:8, 3:10). This shows the importance of being attentive and ready to respond to God's voice with a willing heart.

questions.question: A believer is uncertain about discerning God's voice. Based on 1 Samuel 3, what practical advice would you give?
options: Seek wise counsel and pray for clarity
Ignore it until it feels obvious
Only trust feelings without verification
Avoid sharing it with others
questions.correctAnswer: Seek wise counsel and pray for clarity
questions.explanation: Samuel went to Eli for guidance each time he thought he was called (1 Samuel 3:5-6, 3:8), and Eli instructed him on how to respond (1 Samuel 3:9). This emphasizes the value of spiritual mentorship and prayer in discerning God's voice.

questions.question: What lesson on obedience and faithfulness can we learn from Samuel's behavior in 1 Samuel 3?
options: Obedience requires humility and willingness
Obedience is optional when unsure
Faith is proven only by public acts
We should wait for perfect clarity before acting
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience requires humility and willingness
questions.explanation: Samuel obeyed Eli's instructions and responded to God’s call even before fully understanding the message (1 Samuel 3:9-10, 3:19). His faith involved humble submission and readiness to serve.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about sharing difficult truths in family or church life?
options: Be honest and transparent, even when the message is hard
Hide troubling news to avoid conflict
Delay sharing until feelings subside
Let others speak on your behalf
questions.correctAnswer: Be honest and transparent, even when the message is hard
questions.explanation: Samuel did not hide anything from Eli regarding the LORD’s message, even though it was difficult (1 Samuel 3:17-18). This highlights integrity and courage in communication within family and church.

questions.question: A parent struggles with disciplining their children who have gone astray. What biblical insight from 1 Samuel 3 would you share?
options: Parental responsibility includes restraining wrongdoing
Ignore children’s faults to maintain peace
Punishment is unnecessary if children repent later
Children’s actions don’t affect parental standing
questions.correctAnswer: Parental responsibility includes restraining wrongdoing
questions.explanation: The LORD judged Eli’s house because Eli restrained not his sons from making themselves vile (1 Samuel 3:13-14). This teaches that parents must actively guide and discipline their children.

questions.question: How can 1 Samuel 3 encourage believers to trust God during times when His word seems rare or unclear?
options: Trust that God is still working and will reveal His word
Assume God is silent and act independently
Stop seeking God’s guidance temporarily
Follow human wisdom exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God is still working and will reveal His word
questions.explanation: The chapter opens saying 'the word of the LORD was precious in those days; there was no open vision' (1 Samuel 3:1), yet God called Samuel and revealed His word. This encourages perseverance in faith and trust.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 3 teach about humility in spiritual growth and leadership?
options: Samuel grew in the LORD and let none of His words fall to the ground
Samuel boasted about his prophetic role
Samuel avoided responsibility as long as possible
Samuel sought personal glory first
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel grew in the LORD and let none of His words fall to the ground
questions.explanation: Samuel's growth and faithfulness (1 Samuel 3:19) demonstrate humility and obedience in spiritual leadership instead of pride or self-promotion.

questions.question: True or False: Eli immediately understood that God was calling Samuel after the first time Samuel responded.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Eli only perceived that the LORD was calling Samuel after the third time (1 Samuel 3:8), showing the need for patience and discernment in spiritual matters.

questions.question: True or False: Samuel was afraid to tell Eli the vision he received from God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel feared to show Eli the vision at first (1 Samuel 3:15), illustrating human fear in facing difficult divine messages but still ultimately obeying.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to hear God’s voice clearly. Based on 1 Samuel 3, what biblical virtue would help them persevere?
options: Perseverance through repeated seeking and openness
Giving up after initial confusion
Avoiding spiritual mentors
Rejecting God’s call until perfect clarity
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance through repeated seeking and openness
questions.explanation: Samuel heard God calling three times and kept responding, demonstrating perseverance in spiritual discipline (1 Samuel 3:4-10).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 3 illustrate the importance of integrity in sharing God’s word with others?
options: Samuel told Eli everything without hiding anything
Samuel altered the message to make it easier
Samuel shared only positive news
Samuel kept the message secret
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel told Eli everything without hiding anything
questions.explanation: Samuel reported all that the LORD said to Eli without hiding or altering it (1 Samuel 3:18), showing the necessity of honesty in ministry and witness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When Eli instructed Samuel what to say if called, he told him to say, '______, LORD; for thy servant heareth.'
options: Speak
Listen
Answer
Obey
questions.correctAnswer: Speak
questions.explanation: Eli told Samuel to say 'Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth' if God called him again, showing readiness to listen and obey (1 Samuel 3:9-10).

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 3 reveal about God's faithfulness in calling and equipping His servants?
options: God’s word did not fall to the ground and was fulfilled
God called but did not follow through
God’s servants often fail without hope
God’s message was ignored
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word did not fall to the ground and was fulfilled
questions.explanation: The LORD was with Samuel and let none of his words fall to the ground (1 Samuel 3:19), demonstrating God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises through His servants.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 3 encourage believers regarding God's revelation in their lives and church community?
options: God reveals Himself and His word even in times of spiritual quietness
God only reveals Himself through dramatic signs
God’s revelation is limited to a chosen few
God no longer speaks to His people
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals Himself and His word even in times of spiritual quietness
questions.explanation: Though 'there was no open vision' (1 Samuel 3:1), God appeared again in Shiloh and revealed Himself to Samuel (1 Samuel 3:21), showing that God continues to speak to His people.

questions.question: What practical lesson about spiritual mentorship does 1 Samuel 3 provide for church leaders?
options: Leaders should guide and help others recognize God’s voice
Leaders should keep spiritual experiences private
Leaders must demand unquestioning obedience without explanation
Leaders should focus on ritual over personal guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should guide and help others recognize God’s voice
questions.explanation: Eli helped Samuel understand and respond to God's calling (1 Samuel 3:8-9), illustrating the vital role of mentors in nurturing spiritual growth.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 3.

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel responding 'Here am I' when the LORD calls him in 1 Samuel 3:4?
options: It shows his willingness to serve God
It indicates confusion about who called him
It is a traditional greeting to Eli
It signifies Samuel's fear of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: It shows his willingness to serve God
questions.explanation: Samuel's response 'Here am I' (1 Samuel 3:4) reflects his readiness and openness to God's call, a motif seen throughout Scripture where God's servants respond affirmatively.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 3:7, why is it significant that Samuel 'did not yet know the LORD' nor had the word of the LORD been revealed to him?
options: It emphasizes Samuel's initial spiritual innocence
It shows Eli's failure as a priest
It explains why Samuel ignored the first calls
It reveals that Samuel was not yet a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Samuel's initial spiritual innocence
questions.explanation: The verse highlights Samuel's lack of prior revelation, emphasizing that this chapter marks the beginning of his prophetic vocation, a key theme in Israel's prophetic tradition.

questions.question: How does Eli's instruction to Samuel in 1 Samuel 3:9 ('Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth') foreshadow prophetic obedience?
options: It models the ideal response of a prophet to God's call
It shows Eli doubting God's voice
It is a command to Samuel to ignore the visions
It reveals Eli's own prophetic role
questions.correctAnswer: It models the ideal response of a prophet to God's call
questions.explanation: Eli's instruction prepares Samuel to receive God's message obediently, prefiguring the prophetic humility and readiness that define biblical prophets (1 Samuel 3:9).

questions.question: What does the LORD's message to Samuel about judging Eli's house (1 Samuel 3:11-14) illustrate about divine justice in the Hebrew Bible?
options: God's judgment is irrevocable and based on iniquity
God always forgives the sins of priests
God punishes only the children, not the parents
God's promises can be revoked by human actions
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is irrevocable and based on iniquity
questions.explanation: The passage underscores that divine judgment is just and final, particularly for leaders who fail in their responsibilities, reflecting a recurring biblical motif (1 Samuel 3:11-14).

questions.question: Which literary device is evident in the threefold calling of Samuel by the LORD in 1 Samuel 3:4-8?
options: Tricolon, emphasizing divine persistence
Chiasm, highlighting reversal
Parallelism, contrasting Eli and Samuel
Allegory, representing Israel's history
questions.correctAnswer: Tricolon, emphasizing divine persistence
questions.explanation: The triple call is a tricolon, a rhetorical device used to emphasize God's persistence in calling Samuel, a common feature in Hebrew narrative to mark important moments (1 Samuel 3:4-8).

questions.question: How does the cultural context of priestly failure in 1 Samuel 3:13 relate to broader ancient Near Eastern practices?
options: Priests were expected to maintain moral and ritual purity
Priests often acted independently without accountability
Priestly iniquity was generally overlooked
Only kings were responsible for religious order
questions.correctAnswer: Priests were expected to maintain moral and ritual purity
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, priests were custodians of ritual and moral order, so the failure of Eli's sons and Eli's restraint reflects a serious breach, explaining the severe divine judgment (1 Samuel 3:13).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Samuel fearing to show Eli the vision in 1 Samuel 3:15?
options: It reflects the weight of prophetic revelation and judgment
It indicates Samuel's lack of faith
It suggests Eli was untrustworthy
It shows Samuel's reluctance to become a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the weight of prophetic revelation and judgment
questions.explanation: Samuel's fear demonstrates the solemnity and potential consequences of divine revelation, a common theme where prophets bear heavy burdens (1 Samuel 3:15).

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 3:20, the phrase 'from Dan even to Beersheba' is used. What does this expression signify?
options: The entire territory of Israel from north to south
Only the southern regions of Israel
The area around Shiloh exclusively
The tribal lands of Dan and Beersheba only
questions.correctAnswer: The entire territory of Israel from north to south
questions.explanation: This phrase is a biblical idiom denoting the whole land of Israel, emphasizing the widespread recognition of Samuel's prophetic role (1 Samuel 3:20).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 3:1, 'the word of the LORD was precious' means that the word of God was abundant and freely received in those days.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The phrase 'the word of the LORD was precious' implies it was rare and valuable, highlighting a time when prophetic revelation was scarce (1 Samuel 3:1).

questions.question: What does the lamp of God going out in the temple (1 Samuel 3:3) symbolically represent in the context of this chapter?
options: The waning of divine revelation before Samuel's call
The physical end of the temple service
A sign that Samuel should stop ministering
The extinguishing of the ark of God
questions.correctAnswer: The waning of divine revelation before Samuel's call
questions.explanation: The lamp going out metaphorically signals a period of spiritual darkness or lack of open vision, setting the stage for Samuel's prophetic awakening (1 Samuel 3:3).

questions.question: How does Samuel's prophetic role in 1 Samuel 3 relate to the role of prophets in later biblical books such as Isaiah or Jeremiah?
options: Samuel is a foundational prophet who establishes the pattern of receiving and delivering God's word
Samuel's role is unique and unrelated to later prophets
Samuel only serves as a priest, not a prophet
Samuel's prophecies are purely local and not theological
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel is a foundational prophet who establishes the pattern of receiving and delivering God's word
questions.explanation: Samuel's call and obedience set a precedent for the prophetic office, as seen in later prophets who also receive divine messages to communicate to Israel (1 Samuel 3:19-21).

questions.question: What is the significance of the LORD appearing again in Shiloh to Samuel as stated in 1 Samuel 3:21?
options: It marks Shiloh as a continuing center of divine revelation
It signifies the end of Shiloh's religious importance
It shows Samuel's rejection of Eli's house
It indicates the LORD's withdrawal from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It marks Shiloh as a continuing center of divine revelation
questions.explanation: The reference to the LORD revealing Himself again in Shiloh reinforces the town's role as a sacred site and the place where prophetic communication occurs (1 Samuel 3:21).

questions.question: How does the judgment pronounced against Eli's house in 1 Samuel 3 reflect the theme of covenant accountability in the Hebrew Scriptures?
options: It demonstrates that leaders are accountable for their family's sins
It shows that only prophets face covenant accountability
It indicates that sacrifices can always atone for sin
It suggests that God's covenant is unconditional
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates that leaders are accountable for their family's sins
questions.explanation: The judgment against Eli's house highlights that covenant leadership entails responsibility for moral integrity, consistent with covenant themes of blessing and curses (1 Samuel 3:12-14).

questions.question: What is the function of the phrase 'let none of his words fall to the ground' in 1 Samuel 3:19 in the context of prophetic authority?
options: It emphasizes the certainty and fulfillment of Samuel's prophecies
It suggests Samuel's words were ignored
It means Samuel spoke only in parables
It implies Samuel's prophecies were conditional
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the certainty and fulfillment of Samuel's prophecies
questions.explanation: This phrase highlights the reliability and divine backing of Samuel's prophetic message, a crucial aspect of prophetic legitimacy (1 Samuel 3:19).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 3:18, Samuel hid part of the LORD's message from Eli out of fear.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Samuel told Eli everything without hiding anything, demonstrating honesty and obedience to God's command (1 Samuel 3:18).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What condition describes the spiritual climate in Israel during Samuel's youth?
options: The word of the LORD was precious and there was no open vision
The people worshiped God sincerely
Prophets were widespread and many visions were given
Israel was experiencing great revival
questions.correctAnswer: The word of the LORD was precious and there was no open vision
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:1 states that 'the word of the LORD was precious in those days; there was no open vision,' indicating a time of spiritual drought. This fits the biblical theme of God’s revelation being rare in times of apostasy (cf. Amos 8:11, Hebrews 1:1, Joel 2:28, John 1:17).

questions.question: Why did Samuel initially run to Eli when he heard his name called?
options: Because he thought Eli had called him
Because Samuel was afraid of the LORD
Because Eli told him to come
Because the temple doors were open
questions.correctAnswer: Because he thought Eli had called him
questions.explanation: Verses 4-6 show Samuel answering 'Here am I' and running to Eli, mistakenly thinking Eli called him. This highlights human limitations in discerning God’s voice without spiritual training or revelation (cf. John 10:27, 1 John 4:1, Psalm 25:4-5, Isaiah 30:21).

questions.question: What was Eli’s instruction to Samuel when he realized the LORD was calling the boy?
options: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
Go and tell the people
Pray for a sign
Do not answer the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:9 records Eli instructing Samuel to respond to God with 'Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth,' showing the proper posture of humility and readiness to hear God’s word (cf. Isaiah 6:8, Psalm 40:6, John 10:27, Revelation 3:20).

questions.question: How many times did the LORD call Samuel before Eli understood it was God calling?
options: Three times
Once
Twice
Four times
questions.correctAnswer: Three times
questions.explanation: The LORD called Samuel three times (1 Samuel 3:4, 6, 8), demonstrating God’s patience and persistence in calling a servant. This echoes biblical patterns of God’s repeated calling to His prophets (cf. Isaiah 6:8, Jeremiah 1:4-5, Luke 5:4-10, Acts 9:3-6).

questions.question: What significant message did the LORD reveal to Samuel concerning Eli's house?
options: Judgment would come upon Eli's house forever due to iniquity
Eli's house would be blessed for their faithfulness
Samuel would become the new priest
The temple would be destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment would come upon Eli's house forever due to iniquity
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 3:11-14, the LORD reveals judgment against Eli's house because of sin and failure to restrain his sons. This reflects God's holiness and justice, highlighting divine judgment for sin (cf. Numbers 32:23, Ezekiel 18:20, Romans 6:23, Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What reason did God give for judging Eli's house?
options: Because Eli’s sons made themselves vile and he restrained them not
Because Eli worshiped other gods
Because Eli refused to listen to Samuel
Because Eli destroyed the ark of the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Because Eli’s sons made themselves vile and he restrained them not
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:13 explains God's judgment was due to the iniquity of Eli’s sons and Eli’s failure to restrain them, underscoring responsibility of leadership and accountability (cf. Ezekiel 3:18-19, Proverbs 29:2, 1 Timothy 3:5, Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: What did God swear concerning the purging of Eli's house's iniquity?
options: It shall not be purged with sacrifice nor offering forever
It will be purged after many sacrifices
It will be purged through a prophet
It was already forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: It shall not be purged with sacrifice nor offering forever
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:14 declares that Eli’s house’s iniquity would not be purged by sacrifice or offering forever, emphasizing that some sins require ultimate judgment beyond ritual cleansing (cf. Hebrews 10:4, Isaiah 1:11-17, Psalm 51:16-17, Micah 6:6-8).

questions.question: How did Samuel respond after receiving the vision and message from the LORD?
options: He feared to show Eli the vision
He immediately told all the people
He destroyed the temple
He hid the vision forever
questions.correctAnswer: He feared to show Eli the vision
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 3:15, Samuel feared to show Eli the vision, illustrating the reverence and awe proper in receiving divine revelation (cf. Daniel 10:8-9, Ezekiel 3:14, Habakkuk 2:1, Revelation 1:17).

questions.question: What was Eli’s reaction when Samuel finally told him the entire message from the LORD?
options: He said, 'It is the LORD: let him do what seemeth him good'
He rejected the message angrily
He ignored Samuel
He asked Samuel to keep it secret
questions.correctAnswer: He said, 'It is the LORD: let him do what seemeth him good'
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:18 records Eli’s acceptance of God’s judgment, showing submission to divine sovereignty (cf. Job 1:21, Psalm 115:3, Romans 9:20-21, Proverbs 16:9).

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 3:19 suggest about the reliability of Samuel's prophetic words?
options: The LORD was with him and let none of his words fall to the ground
His words were often ignored
His words were sometimes inaccurate
The people rejected all his words
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD was with him and let none of his words fall to the ground
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:19 highlights God’s presence with Samuel and the certainty of his prophetic words, affirming the divine inspiration and infallibility of true prophecy (cf. 2 Peter 1:21, Jeremiah 1:9, Ezekiel 2:7, Matthew 24:35).

questions.question: What geographical extent is mentioned regarding Samuel's recognition as a prophet?
options: From Dan even to Beersheba
Only in Shiloh
Throughout Egypt
From Jerusalem to Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: From Dan even to Beersheba
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:20 states all Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew Samuel was established as a prophet, indicating widespread recognition throughout Israel, consistent with prophetic ministry impacting the entire covenant community (cf. Joshua 20:7, Judges 20:1, 2 Chronicles 30:5, Acts 10:36).

questions.question: Where did the LORD appear to Samuel as He revealed Himself by the word of the LORD?
options: In Shiloh
On Mount Sinai
In Jerusalem
In Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: In Shiloh
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:21 states the LORD appeared again in Shiloh to Samuel by the word of the LORD, emphasizing the location of God's covenant presence and prophetic revelation (cf. Joshua 18:1, Psalm 78:60, Jeremiah 7:12, John 1:14).

questions.question: What does the calling of Samuel in 1 Samuel 3 teach about God's method of revealing Himself to His servants?
options: God calls personally and repeatedly, requiring readiness and obedience
God only reveals Himself through signs and wonders
God speaks only to kings and priests
God's revelation is always loud and unmistakable
questions.correctAnswer: God calls personally and repeatedly, requiring readiness and obedience
questions.explanation: The narrative shows God calling Samuel three times and instructing him to respond 'Speak, LORD,' indicating God’s personal, persistent communication that calls for attentive obedience (1 Samuel 3:4-10; cf. Isaiah 6:8, Jeremiah 1:4-10, John 10:27, Hebrews 11:6).

questions.question: What theological truth about God's justice and mercy is highlighted by the judgment pronounced on Eli’s house?
options: God’s holiness demands judgment on sin, but His word continues through chosen servants
God ignores sin if mercy is requested
God punishes entire nations without cause
God’s mercy means no judgment will come
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness demands judgment on sin, but His word continues through chosen servants
questions.explanation: The judgment on Eli’s house (1 Samuel 3:11-14) shows that God's holiness requires punishment of persistent sin, but He preserves His covenant through prophets like Samuel, illustrating divine justice balanced with mercy (cf. Exodus 34:6-7, Psalm 89:30-34, Romans 3:25-26, Hebrews 1:1-2).

questions.question: How does Samuel’s fear to reveal the vision to Eli (1 Samuel 3:15) reflect the nature of divine revelation in the life of a prophet?
options: Divine revelation carries weight and often causes reverent fear
Prophets always reveal visions immediately without hesitation
Divine visions are always encouraging and joyful
Fear shows lack of faith in God’s message
questions.correctAnswer: Divine revelation carries weight and often causes reverent fear
questions.explanation: Samuel’s fear (1 Samuel 3:15) reflects the serious and sometimes terrifying nature of receiving God’s message, consistent with other prophetic experiences (cf. Isaiah 6:5, Ezekiel 1:28, Daniel 10:8, Revelation 1:17). This underscores the sacred responsibility of speaking God’s truth.

questions.question: What does Samuel’s growth and the LORD’s presence with him (1 Samuel 3:19) teach about the development of prophetic ministry?
options: Prophetic ministry matures with God’s continual presence and confirmation
Prophets act independently of God’s guidance
Prophets are only recognized after death
Prophetic ministry is based on human wisdom alone
questions.correctAnswer: Prophetic ministry matures with God’s continual presence and confirmation
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 3:19 affirms that Samuel grew and the LORD was with him, ensuring the truth and efficacy of his words, illustrating that genuine prophetic ministry depends on God’s presence and guidance (cf. Exodus 33:15-17, Numbers 12:6-8, John 14:26, Acts 2:17-18).
